ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read with objective. There was a lot of reading in this class, and I had to learn how to finish the material and also be efficient with my time.  I also think the writing lab was somewhat useful in helping me with close reading.

How to analyze literature in a context that is NOT focused on literary devices and specific elements of the writing. How to approach broader concepts and generate your own prompts/answers based on ideas from the texts.

From the lab, I was able to expand my writing abilities in a myriad of ways and begin to find out my personal strengths and weaknesses in writing. In the class, I was able to engage with a variety of media that I never would have sought out if it were not for this class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved our discussions in the seminar, but I think the writing lab has a lot of room for improvement. Sometimes the professors would give instructions and then contradict themselves in the next sentence. The writing lab felt aimless at times, and three hours on a Friday was a long time to have every week.

Strengths: Central theme, relaxed and comfortable (albeit sad) setting, supportive and kind faculty 
Weaknesses: labs were long and painful, I often felt like I would have gotten more work done outside of lab than in lab.

For the class, I felt at times that the reading load was a bit intense to the point that I had a difficult time fully diving into, or even just remembering all the details of the texts we were reading. For the lab, my biggest critique is that I think that there was a lot of unnecessary talk that ate up writing time. I think that the 3 hour lab should either be shorter or focus more on peer work and direct engagement with reading, writing, and reviewing. I felt at times that our talking sessions involved the professors telling the students things they already knew or could at least assume during the course. Getting straight to the more hands-on material would be more valuable for giving the readers something to take away.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I am conflicted in recommending this course, because I really enjoyed the seminar part of this course, but had a few issues with the writing lab.

Yes! Even though I never imagined I'd be reading and writing about dogs during my time at Yale I felt like it was an interesting divergence from the standard cut and dry writing many are familiar with in high school.

I didn't always find the subject material of this class to be interesting but it was still fun to discuss and write about, so yes I would recommend the course to a fellow student. I would also recommend the other 6PGX courses though and encourage them to find which one they think works best and interests them the most.
